Incorporating strength training into your routine can have a huge impact on your running efficiency and endurance. The core and glutes are indeed crucial areas to focus on, as they play a vital role in stabilizing your body, generating power, and propelling you forward. Here are some exercises that target these areas, which I highly recommend for runners:

**Core Exercises:**

1. **Plank:** Hold a plank position for 30-60 seconds, rest for 30 seconds, and repeat for 3-5 sets. This exercise targets your entire core, including your abs, obliques, and lower back.
2. **Russian twists:** Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a weight or medicine ball and twist your torso from side to side, targeting your obliques. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
3. **Leg raises:** Lie on your back with arms extended overhead and raise your legs straight up towards the ceiling. Lower your legs back down without touching the floor, and repeat for 3 sets of 12-15 reps. This targets your lower abs.
4. **Side plank (each side):** Hold a side plank position for 30-60 seconds, rest for 30 seconds, and repeat on the other side. This targets your obliques and hip stabilizers.

**Glute Exercises:**

1. **Squats:** Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and perform a squat, keeping your back straight and engaging your glutes. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
2. **Deadlifts:** Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight or barbell with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lift the weight up and stand up straight, squeezing your glutes at the top. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
3. **Glute bridges:** Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips up towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top, and repeat for 3 sets of 12-15 reps.
4. **Lunges:** Stand with your feet together and take a large step forward with one foot. Lower your body down into a lunge, keeping your back straight and engaging your glutes. Do 3 sets of 12-15 reps on each leg.

**Additional Tips:**

* Start with lower reps and sets and gradually increase as you build strength and endurance.
* Focus on controlled movements and proper form to avoid injury.
* Incorporate exercises that target your hip flexors, such as leg swings and hip circles, to improve your running form and efficiency.
* Aim to do strength training exercises 2-3 times a week, with at least one day of rest in between.

Remember, consistency and patience are key. Incorporating strength training into your routine will take time, but it will pay off in the long run (pun intended!).
